author: Brian
title: 4 months in and Apple changed some things...
types: Size: 42mmStyle: Silver Aluminum with White Sport Band
body: My Wife and I bought ourselves these watches for our Christmas gifts to each other in 2018. We were looking for good fitness watches as well as accessories for our iPhones. She had a 7 plus and I have a 6S.First, the non-fitness aspects: It took roughly a month to really feel like I knew my watch fairly well. I use it a lot for notifications in meetings, quick responses when I’m on the road and for quickly pinging to find where my phone is. I also like it for the flashlight for times when I need to see but not have it too bright like getting ready in the morning before my wife and daughter wake up.Unfortunately, the voice to text is somewhat lacking compared to my iPhone 6S. I find the interpretation is often way off on many words and you can’t just go back and change a word like you can on a phone. You have to repeat the whole sentence.I also have trouble with getting Siri to auto trigger sometimes when I tilt my wrist up. I’m not sure why it works well sometimes and not at all other times.The battery life is decent but I wish it could run longer for a watch. I feel like 2 days and maybe half a day more is the max you can go without charging it. It does charge fairly quickly though. I think around 2 hours.I also wish there were more customizable faces. I can’t find the perfect face with everything I want on it. Animation, rings, weather, time, date and quick workout access.Overall, I’d rate this watch about a 3 & 1/2 stars for its non-fitness aspects. If the Siri worked better and talk to text worked better I would probably give it another star. Also, sometimes it’s hard to hear me if I’m in my car as well as hear other people on it. It’s still a good accessory though.Now, onto the fitness aspects of the watch.I loved this watch for fitness reasons when I first got it. It inspired me to workout more and around Feb I began completing my workout goals (rings) and actually begin losing weight. It helped me to lose 20 lbs. yay!It wasn’t until about a month ago I started having issues. What happened? It stopped giving me credit for some of my exercises. For example, I went on a 23 minute walk outside today with the Outside walk workout running and got 11 minutes of credit for it. I have since researched the issue to find out this was done on purpose by Apple. Or so they are claiming.What’s going on? Apple has an algorithm that apparently determines your heart rate, speed of walking and health information and if you don’t meet the minimum for a “brisk walk” then you don’t get credit for it in the exercise minutes. What idiot at apple decided this was a good idea? A healthy heart will have a lower beat rate but it doesn’t mean you aren’t exercising for that duration. This puts me off tremendously and I feel there needs I be a choice for the user to turn this auto calculation off and be able to use the workouts as they were before the change was made.Apple even gives a work around for this issue that makes no sense to me. They say just use the “other” workout and it will count as workout time. But what about the distance? The gps map? The ability to track how many walks you’ve taken and for how long? I feel like they’ve brushed it off and not addressed the issue here at all and that attitude towards the consumer’s concerns is a major turn off for me. What should be a solid 4-5 star fitness watch is now a 1 star fitness watch until this is addressed by apple.Until then, I can not recommend this watch as a fitness accessory. It’s a decent accessory to the iPhone if you need it for the non-fitness reasons.

author: Evelyn
title: Bricked on update; thrown under the bus by Apple "Care"
types: Size: 38mmStyle: Silver Aluminum with White Sport Band
body: Initially I loved this watch. I purchased it for the haptic alerts, as I frequently miss phone calls when my phone's in my bag or another room. For a brief time the watch was well suited to this purpose, and also quite handy for step tracking and fitness motivation.Sadly, after using the watch for a year, I became aware of a fatal flaw with the product. As a result, I’m now the proud owner of a bricked watch, with no remedy in sight from Apple. The flaw is a little-known issue with software updates. As the watch has no externally facing ports, WatchOS is initially installed prior to the watch case being sealed. In each WatchOS update, the OS carefully replaces itself with the new version. If anything goes amiss during a critical stage of the update (like hitting the cancel button, a lack of network connectivity, power failure, or nudging the watch off the magnetic charger), the watch is potentially left with the red exclamation mark of death (pictured) - and, assuming a hard reset fails, no possible means of ever restoring a working OS onto the watch again.In some instances where this happens, Apple quietly takes the watch and replaces it with a brand new one, hoping that customers will be so relieved about this wasteful "fix" that they don't mention the dirty little design flaw to too many other people. This is all fine and dandy if you're still within the one year warranty period, and you don't move away from the place of purchase. HOWEVER, if your watch borks itself during the update following the one year mark, OR you happen to have the misfortune of moving to a region with a subtly different model (which I regrettably did), you can expect to be up the creek. This happened to my watch at the 14 month mark. Now, after four maddening weeks of Apple "Care" stuffing me around and sending me on a 3-hour goose chase to my nearest Apple Store, I'm left with a useless device and a slap-in-the-face voucher for $45 off a new one (thanks, but no thanks!).If the red exclamation mark of death ever happens to you, you need to be aware and informed about your rights. Apple will probably try to tell you that your device had a pre-existing but somehow previously unseen hardware issue, and that they aren’t obliged to help you 1) after 12 months or 2) outside the country of purchase. What you need to know is: 1) Apple is legally obliged to provide you with working SOFTWARE for your device EVEN AFTER the 12 month US hardware warranty period has expired, and 2) this is often only a hardware problem of Apple's own making. It was Apple's own design choice to seal the case, preventing simple software issues from being remedied in software alone - and Apple must assume responsibility for the absurd consequence that a partially-installed OS results in a permanently bricked device. Given Apple's woeful track record of accepting responsibility for glaring design flaws, I predict this will once again end in a consumer class action - just like the infamous failure-prone MacBook butterfly keyboards and the self-shredding MagSafe power adaptors. Hell, there's at least one class action already on this very model of Apple Watch - related to cracking and shattering of screens. Caveat emptor - buyer beware!

author: Rick Blaine
title: Have one - works great, but PLEASE read the review
types: Size: 38mmStyle: Space Gray Aluminum with Black Sport Band
body: I have an Apple 3 GPS 38MM and it works fine, does everything all the 4 and 5 star reviews says it will do - just don't make the mistake I did. I was seduced by the cheap-o Chinese knock offs which are now available by the dozen here and at other online sites. Please, just look at the reviews - every which one of them are 5 stars! The reviews say things like "really found the true one which I seached a long time.It's worth to buying." What?!?! These are obviously fake reviews churned out by the hundreds just to get this junk sold. These watches rarely work let alone work as advertised. Bad batteries, zero conectivity, just throw it away if you drop it or it gets wet, horrible band - well, you get the idea. I am not advocating running out and buying an Apple Watch, but I am saying - do your homework. Read the massive amount of 5 star reviews, most of which have been posted on the same day. Don't waste your time and money on these cheap knock offs, you'll be disappointed.

author: Tatum Causey
title: Highly Recommend!
types: Size: 38mmStyle: Silver Aluminum with White Sport Band
body: About a month ago, I purchased an Apple Watch. I am very pleased with this product and everything that it includes. At first, I was skeptical about having another device and worried about it distracting me, but there is something about this that makes phone usage so much more convenient. When I’m busy multitasking, I can quick glance at the message I just received or see who’s calling to make sure I actually want to answer it. With this newest Apple Watch, I am able to pick up a phone call without having my phone actually on me. I am able to monitor and watch my health through this watch too, completing each ring on the watch ensures that I am not spending my entire day sitting around.Pros:• Send and receive text messages• Siri• Fitness tracking• Alarms and Notes• Reminders• Interchangeable bands to match anything• GPSThe GPS is probably my favorite part about the watch. While I am going somewhere, instead of having to hold my phone in front of me, the Apple Watch vibrates and speaks when it is time to turn or take an exit. This makes driving somewhere new much more convenient and also much more safe than holding my phone in front of my face. With the fitness aspect, if I have been sitting for more than an hour, it will remind me to stand up. It also tracks my steps and calories that I burned throughout the day as well. Another huge bonus about the Apple Watch is that it is able to send a call to my phone if I misplace it and vice versa. The battery life of the watch is great, I have gone 3 days without charging it and it’s still on and fully functional.As for some downfalls, it can be just another device to have around that you may not actually need. This is not a necessity, it is a luxury to have an Apple Watch. If you set it up, you will receive social media notifications but are not able to scroll through the actual website. To ensure that you won’t be bothered by these notifications, just don’t log on to the social media site on the watch; unless you want the notifications.Overall, I love this product and highly recommend it to anyone that is skeptical about purchasing one. It makes a great gift for anyone with an iPhone!
